Description: Fragment of circular cipo with a polished surface. Its state of conservation is bad: it needs a piece in the lower part and a bit of the upper one. It has large debris and chipping around its perimeter, especially in the lower left, which is so worn that even the initial letters of the last four lines have been lost. The deterioration affects, to a great extent, the epigraphic text, which could have been reconstructed, however, based on other parallels.
Reasoned classification: We do not know the exact location of this miliary, but it is likely that it was erected on the road called 'Via Augusta' and, specifically, on the section Carthago-Nova-Basti-Acci-Cástulo. There are few milestones that have been preserved around Acci, because when passing the road through fertile lands, near the rivers, these, by erosive processes, have had to drag the miliaries to hide them in their own channels or on the farm lands near them. This would be one of the few examples of this route as it passes through Guadix. From this road section have appeared, so far, 17 miles, of which 5 are from Augusto, one of them, also from our province: Cullar Baza, another, from Numeriano, the one we studied, from Posthumus, and the rest without being able to be precise with accuracy. The first stretch of the road, close to the fertile plain and the rivers (Guadix, Benalúa, Bejarí, Fardes), was intended to take the mining products from the southeast of the peninsula towards the coast. Chronologically, the miliary corresponds to the year 260, one of the years of the government of the Posthumous Emperor: M. Cassianius Latinius Postumus, creator of the Imperium Galliarum (259-268), located on the margin of the Central Empire of Rome and himself considered a usurper . This kingdom included the whole Gallia, from the Rhine to the Rhône, and all of Hispania and Britain. His main task was the fight against the Germans. The titles he receives in coins and inscriptions are the same as those worn by the Roman emperors: Pius, Felix, Invistus, Augustus, Pater Patriae and is covered with the Roman pontificate, the tribunitia potestate, consulate, proconsulate, etc. In his reign these miliarios show their excessive care for the maintenance of Roman roads and roads, so important for the Empire.

Casual find, 1971, Santero Saturino, José Mª
[The Roman town of Paulenca is located about 3 km west of Guadix, in the surroundings of Paulenca, a hamlet attached to the municipality of that town, in an area belonging to the payment of the Ponderosa. The sculpture appeared, along with construction materials and ceramics, when performing works of land recess. The following year an archaeological excavation was carried out.]
Description: Figure called Venus de Paulenca. It represents a woman dressed in a tunic. The sculpture rests on the left leg, which serves as a support, while bending the right, which protrudes at the height of the knee, to later delay the foot. This movement causes a twist that highlights the left hip and gives the figure a suggestive pose. She wears a transparent tunic, cinched by a ribbon under her breasts and leaving the left uncovered. On the tunic he wears a complicated cloak, which he held with his right hand (lost) over his head, in an attitude of covering himself, while the left hand (also lost) came forward, either to hold the folds of the mantle, or to offer a apple or other type of object, in a very characteristic attitude of Venus. The sinuous folds of the mantle, which fall heavily to the right of the figure, until suddenly turning in a whirlwind of curves and finally descend between the two legs, complicate the figure by its baroque. The state of conservation is good, saving the ancient loss of the head and arms and the concretions of the surface of the marble.
Reasoned classification: This small sculpture is likely to be a representation of Aphrodite / Venus, inserted within the ornamental program of the villa. In Roman mythology Venus was an important goddess mainly related to love, beauty and fertility. She was the wife of Vulcan, was considered ancestor of the Roman people through its legendary founder, Aeneas, and played a crucial role in many Roman religious festivals and myths. Roman and Hellenistic art produced many variations on the goddess, often based on the Praxitelian type of the Venus de Milo.

Description:
Cinerary urn made in lead. Morphologically it is a rectangular parallelepiped constructed from a sheet of lead through which the box and lid have been made. This sheet was cut in a T shape, defining the faces that will later form the urn and then folded as if it were a cardboard box. The edges were adjusted by means of flaps folded over them in the areas of the side faces and the lid, so that it is perfectly closed.
The urn lacks decoration and is partially fractured in several of its surfaces.

Find spot: Casa de Juan Cabello, Medina-Sidonia (Janda (comarca), Cádiz <(provincia)>) Hallazgo, 1894
Description: Male statue of a togado, sculpted in marble, missing the head, right forearm, left hand and feet. Dress a tunic that describes folds in V on the chest and, covering it, a toga that rests on the left shoulder and crosses obliquely the torso, forming a pronounced umbo with the folds in U and a broad sinus that falls on the thigh of the right leg. At the back, almost without working, the toga falls in a manner analogous to the way it does on the obverse, joining the folds with the highlights on the sinus itself. The character rests the weight on the left leg, which is slightly ahead of the right, leaving its shape clearly drawn under the clothes. The right arm would presumably fall along the body and the left arm would have the elbow clearly bent upwards, so that the hand would advance towards the front. The frontal carving of the sculpture, barely worked on its reverse, suggests that it was conceived to be seen only in front of it.
Reasoned classification:
Some typological and iconographic elements induce to frame the sculpture around the first century d. C., between the time of Tiberius and Claudius: the large, flat and U-shaped umbo
the broad sinus, whose schematized and flat folds encompass and cover the lower part of the body
the slightly forward leg marked under the garment
the axial continuity between the folds of the tunic, arranged in a V-shape between the neck and the waist, and those of the umbo in the U-shape

Find spot: Medina-Sidonia(Janda (comarca), Cádiz)
Description:
Female marble sculpture dressed in tunic and palla or mantle, which is arranged on the chest in a double curve. The right hand leaves between the folds of the same one holding it near the opposite shoulder, while the rest of the mantle is collected on the left hand and falls vertically. The right leg, slightly flexed, causes the formation of diagonal folds giving dynamism to the figure that contrasts with the verticality of the tunic that appears at the bottom under the mantle.
Some authors consider that due to its formal characteristics this work could be framed within one of the statues types of funerary character called Eumachia-Fundilia. Born in middle Hellenism with a progressive development throughout the 1st century BC. until reaching its peak in the Augustus era. This model will be represented both in funeral stelae and in exempt sculptures.
This typology adopts the scheme of an ideal figure. The women thus presented were Roman citizens belonging to the imperial family or to the upper social classes and had a prominent role in the family and in society. Images of this type are the clearest exponent of the social and political influence and economic power of certain women during the first centuries of the Empire.

Find spot: Cerro del Castillo, Medina-Sidonia (Janda (comarca), Cádiz <(provincia)>)
Description: Female head sculpted in white marble. The most relevant physiognomic features are the large eyes, the broad cheekbones, the small mouth and the short chin. Replica provincial of the type with nodus hairstyle, characterized by the high tupé on the forehead, side wave winders, smooth hair band on the skull and low thick chignon.
Hair: The nodus hairstyle, typical of the Julio-Claudia dynasty, is characterized by the high and marked toupee and a thick, low chignon. The iconographic features correspond to that represented in a bust of the Fayum, preserved in the Ny Carlsberg Glyptotek.
Reasoned classification: The workshop from which the piece proceeds works according to the guidelines of the classicist style, concise and clear of Tiberius's time, solved with correct and unwieldy technique, sometimes neglected. Together with the preserved heads of Druso (Inv. No. CE07442) and Germanicus (Inv. No. CE07210), from the same workshop, he would be part of a sculptural group related to the Julio-Claudia family cult, domus augusta, by their own provincial elites. The heads would be inserted in statues, attached to the wall, judging from the unfinished state of the backs. The group would be presided over by Livia, in the center, with Germanic on his right and Drusus on the left, according to the hierarchical order of succession.

Find spot: Cerro del Castillo, Medina-Sidonia (Janda (comarca), Cádiz <(provincia)>)
Description: Head in marble that represents a young man -Druso the Younger-, of technical and typological characteristics very similar to the portrait preserved in the same Germanicus museum (Inv. No. CE07210), perhaps less accomplished. It has a broad face, with well-marked features and a prominent nose. The hair is solved with a little meticulous carving, which in the case of the right side, the back and top of the head is reduced to the previous work of roughing. The sideburns also run down the face to the jaw with insinuated ripples. The fringe, straight, is even more hieratic and simple than that of Germanicus. Almond-shaped eyes retain traces of having painted the iris
Reasoned classification: The Asidonian workshop where the piece was sculpted responds to the conciseness, clarity and classicism of the Tiberian era. The technique is equally precise and effective, with notable carelessness and saving work in areas outside the viewer's vision. Together with the heads of Livia (Inv. No. CE07209) and Germanic (Inv. No. CE07210) he was part of a sculptural group that exhalted the Julio-Claudia family, the domus augusta, commissioned by provincial elites, antecedent of the imperial cult.

Iconography: togathus The type of toga corresponds to the typical of the imperial period, type B of Goette, "togados of imperial epoch with umbo in the shape of a U", specifically to the variant Ba, corresponding to the toga with umbo in the shape of a U of the century I dC, whose chronology is fixed from the last decade of the first century BC.

Hallazgo, 1894
Description:
Male statue of a togathus, sculpted in marble, missing the head, almost the entire right arm, left forearm and feet. Dress a tunic that describes folds in V on the chest and, covering it, a toga that rests on the left shoulder and crosses obliquely the torso, forming a pronounced umbo with the folds in U and a broad sinus that falls on the thigh of the right leg. At the back, almost without working, the toga falls in a manner analogous to the way it does on the obverse, joining the folds with the highlights on the sinus itself. The character rests the weight on the left leg, which is slightly ahead of the right, leaving its shape clearly drawn under the clothes. The right arm would presumably fall along the body and the position of the left forearm suggests that the elbow would appear flexed upwards, so that the hand would advance forward.
The sculpture presents the back and the left side with a minimum carving, which suggests that it was conceived to be seen mainly from a right-front angle.
Reasoned classification:
Some typological and iconographic elements induce to frame the sculpture around the first century d. C., between the time of Tiberius and Claudius: the large, flat and U-shaped umbo
the broad sinus, whose schematized and flat folds encompass and cover the lower part of the body
the slightly forward leg marked under the garment
the axial continuity between the folds of the tunic, arranged in a V-shape between the neck and the waist, and those of the umbo in the U-shape

Description:
Following Isabel López (1998, pp. 43-44), we describe this sculpture as a toga represented with a tunic with a neckline, which is placed on the chest in a "V" fold, and is pressed at the waist by the 'balteus' giving rise to three curvilinear folds that protrude from the plane of the sculpture. The'umbo 'is formed by a set of wide, irregular and slightly pointed folds that protrude prominently. As for the 'inus', which falls over the right leg, coming from the left shoulder, it is formed by deep and spaced folds that in the inner part are adhered to the right leg, letting glimpse its shape. The treatment of the'ima toga 'allows to see also the anatomical shape of the left leg, as it happens with the right under the'inus'. The weighting is seen in the left leg, standing up, serving as a support, and the right, slightly flexed and carried backwards.
In relation to the treatment of the folds, these are elaborated excellently by the artist, being marked and deep, defined by thick edges
in the back they are more superficially worked, but without neglecting their invoice.
The piece is fractured in its right part on top of the'balteus', in the whole left side and in the superior one, being remains of the hollow for the insertion of the head. The lower part is also incomplete and the back part has multiple intentional breaks. In the central area of ​​the left side a hole is preserved destined to fit part of the'balteus', in whose surface the traces of the pointer work can be seen for better adjustment of this piece, as in the back, for the assembly of the piece corresponding to the longitudinal folds. It presents abundant traces of smoothing and remains of polychrome.
Reasoned classification: According to I. López (1998, p.44), the toga depicted corresponds to the Goette classification, to the Ba type of the Claudia era, having a parallel in the togas from the theater of Leptis Magna and the theater of Caere, also dated in Claudius era. Parallels for this piece are also Tarraco's robes, those of the 'Marble Forum' of Emerita Augusta, dated by Trillmich in the low period of Claudius, and four statues from Cádiz, Asido and Baelo Claudia.

Description:
Anthropomorphic head belonging to the Iberian culture sculpted in white limestone, identified with a horse. Possibly it belonged to an animal body or was attached to some architectural ensemble. The head is composed of a massive block of limestone with an oval shape in the snout that widens and deforms slightly when reaching the temple. The facial features of the animal are made through a series of successful incisions. Thus the mouth of the animal appears slightly open and in which no teeth or lips have been represented. The nose has been indicated by two small incised grimaces in the curved stone that simulate the nostrils. The eyes are almond shaped with the iris being highlighted by a greater recess of the material. In the upper part of the head the animal has two holes that may have been used to place a series of applications that simulate the auditory pavilions, a custom very common in this type of animal.
Detachments can also be seen in the snout, possibly caused by the placement of the animal's own guarcionería, which was also very common to place in this type of pieces during the Iberian period. The quality of the polish of the limestone, which contrasts with certain scratches and fragmentations, is striking. In the upper part of the head and between the holes in which it is thought that there were applications as auditory pavilions, an inscription appears that is summarized as 'RENT'

Description: This figure represents an important personage of the city of Baelo Claudia, possibly a magistrate. It was found in the forum, next to the Temple of Jupiter, in the area dedicated to the Capitoline Triad. He is represented with the toga and at his feet the volumina box (books rolled on an axis). The toga is a symbol of romanity. The individuals who dressed it were Roman citizens and, as such, they had the right to exercise the magistratures proper to the cursus honorum. The represented person held a public position in the city, and the senatus of the same gave him the honor of erecting his sculpture in marble. These statues were placed in the fora and other public places. Only the municipal aristocracy, which monopolizes the high local magistrates, has the economic power to be able to arrive at the position and to contribute to the public charges, including the acts of evergetism. Only she could afford the realization of these monumental sculptures.

Description:
Sculpture of invoice and rough finish, worked in stone that represents a seated lion, laying on its belly, supported on a rectangular platform. It is very affected by erosion. Is in the attitude of devouring a victim, possibly a bovid, cervid or equine, which holds with the right claw that makes prey on the head of the animal, and the left, which grips in its hindquarters. The proportions and details of the deer or equid are only worked on the right side of the neck and head, oval, elongated snout, robust jaw and swollen cheeks, round eye and lanceolate ear.
The head of the lion, which turns to its left, is touched by a mane that frames its face. It has a very wide snout, with a slightly open jaw and large, slightly almond-shaped eyes. There is no solution of continuity between the mane and the back of the feline, although this zone seems especially affected by erosion. The side to which the lion looks is the one that presents a more careful and meticulous size, leaving the forms on the opposite side barely sketched. The tail wraps around the upper third of the left hind leg. The front legs present a work with some detail of the claws of the animal

Aunque por ahora hay una ausencia de esculturas funerarias de leones en el ámbito turdetano del Bajo Guadalquivir (Beltrán 2000: 437
Pérez 1999: 22), el hecho es que los leones como el descrito aparecidos en época romana lo hacen en áreas coincidentes con focos antiguos de estas imágenes (el Alto Guadalquivir y la zona próxima del la cuenca baja del río). 
En el Bajo Guadalquivir el modelo iconográfico documentado es el del león, en este caso recostado sobre sus cuartos traseros, asociados a cabezas de animales como presas. Esculturas como ésta podrían haber funcionado como tapaderas de cista o podrían haber formado parte de monumentos funerarios de mayor entidad, situados en las esquinas de los remates de cubos elevados sobre podios, al estilo ítalo-romano (cfr. Pérez 1999: 28-31, fig. 18-20
en contra: Beltrán 2000: 441, nota 10). 
El hecho de que la gran mayoría de estas esculturas han aparecido descontextualizadas dificulta la datación de las mismas, que debe hacerse fundamentalmente en atención a criterios iconográficos, comparando en gran medida con los paralelos más conocidos del área itálica. Éstos apuntan a un arco relativamente amplio que discurre entre el siglo II a.C. (si tomamos en consideración el dudoso contexto del león de la necrópolis de Cádiz, nº inv. CE04585 - cfr. Pérez 1999: 28, 30, 34-35, fig. 19) y mediados del siglo I d.C. (Beltrán 2002: 242). Para el caso de los leones de Carissa Aurelia se propone una cronología centrada entre el siglo II a.C. y el cambio de Era (Pérez 1999: 32)

The tomb of an approximately six-year-old boy is one of the most remarkable portrait features of the largest and most elaborate tomb of Carmona, measuring 34 x 38 m. In the same grave also the inscribed grave statue of Servilia was found in the type of the great Herculean and a very high-quality male portrait of the years around AD 40, in which one known from the inscription CIL II 5120 Praefectus of Caligula and Ouattuorvirn L. Servilius Polio wanted to recognize.
The child was undoubtedly an early-dead member of this family of the municipal aristocracy. In the portrayals of the portraits, which, moreover, are carried out with great powers of observation and sculptural skill, the infantile proportions of the body form a certain contrast to the expression of the facial features, which seem to indicate a somewhat later age.
The lanky hairstyle, which fits snugly in the head, with a fork over the left eye, in connection with the delicately flickered incarnate, suggests a date in Claudian times.

The neckline indicates that it served to fit into the body of a larger statue, possibly with a military breastplate. Description: Part of a head, missing the upper section sectioned in bevel and part of the neck, which represents an adult man, with correct features and rather short proportions, pronounced chin and jaw line sharp and strong. The head tilted to the right, turning smoothly in the same direction. The contours are clearly drawn, as we see on the eyelids and lips. The modeling is careful and naturalistic, with soft lines on the cheeks and neck. The hair is resolved into bands of flat tufts, clearly separated, in opposite directions between one row and another. The head would be integrated into the provincial style, although following the most general guidelines of the official portrait. The treatment of the hair denotes the saving of habitual work in the provincial workshops. On the other hand, the influence of official portraiture is perceived in the invoice and treatment of the conserved eye, with the upper eyelid high, plastically individualized, and the lacrimal meticulously drawn, and the mouth softly modeled but well marked. The portrait has striking similarities with those of Augustus and Tiberius.

Description:
Male statue of a togado, sculpted in marble, missing the head and forearms. Dress a tunic that describes V-shaped folds on the chest and, covering it, a toga that rests on the left shoulder and crosses obliquely the torso, forming a pronounced umbo with the folds in U and a sinus that falls on the thigh of the leg right. On the back, scarcely carved, the toga falls in a manner analogous to the way it does on the obverse, joining the folds with the highlights on the sinus itself. The character advances the left foot while the right is left behind, leaning slightly on the left front of the plant. This leg is, thus, slightly flexed, as seen under the modeling of the toga. A kind of tree trunk or vegetal motif with unidentifiable leaves is attached to the left leg. The figure is covered with the typical calceus patricius, with two strips, which leaves the front of the foot covered by the thin skin (aluta), while behind it is covered by the later frame of the footwear, coarser.
The right arm falls along the body, slightly forward, and the left has the elbow clearly bent upwards, so that the hand would come forward to the front. The whole figure is supported on a slightly irregular pedestal, worked only on his forehead, which suggests that the statue would be conceived for his frontal vision.

Description: Figure exempt of lion, carved in limestone of whitish-grayish hue. It does not keep its head, but the position of the neck indicates that it was oriented to the right. It is in a crouched position, with its front legs on the ground and its hind legs upright. The anatomical features are briefly indicated, including sex. Remains of the mane around the neck are appreciated, based on three parallel bands of incisions. A quadrangular plinth holds the whole figure. In addition to the face, it has lost the right claw and part of the mane. Originally it was coated and polychrome. The figures of lions are one of the most common elements of the funerary world of the Lower Guadalquivir during the s. II a.C. until the change of Era. They are attributed to a tomb model of Italic origin, in which a pair of lions crowned the upper part of the monument as a "apotrópaion" (protection against the forces of evil). The lion of Las Cabezas was found old in the town, and donated in 1918 to the Museum by the City Council at the proposal of Gabriel Lupiáñez. From the formal point of view it has its own characteristics that bring it closer to the oldest productions of the republican era, possibly dating to the second half of the 20th century. II a. C. (Pérez, 1999: 20) or even something earlier (Chapa, 1985: 106). Its schematism equates it with another specimen preserved in this Museum (DO7929), from Cortijo del Infierno en Espera, Cádiz. Both share a similar technical composition and seem to have held an animal's head under the paw. Surely he was on the upper left side of the grave

Male portrait with beard and curly hair worked in trephine, nude and conserved up to the pectorals, which responds to traditional forms in particular portraits of the Antonine era. Made in white marble with high quality work, it is larger than the natural size and retains part of a slight reddish varnish. It is remarkable how to reproduce the materiality of the curls of the hairstyle and the beard based on protuberances, in which the trephine pierces small cavities that proliferate in the manner of cells. The pupils are engraved without large gaps that shade it. The bare chest is hollow at the back and carries a drill to be threaded with a bolt.
The nose and the lower right edge of the bust are missing and there are breaks and small damages in the eyes, right cheek, lower lip, ears and central tufts of the hair. The head was severed and the neck fractured by several parts joined by the sculptor Mateo Inurria.

On the other hand, the mantle rests on the shoulders, unfolds throughout the back and curves in the right hip, having been elaborated the folds in its right lateral line and barely insinuated. [...] Between the legs the tissue is concentrated in oblique folds of different depths that promote chiaroscuro in this area. [...] From the right hip to the left forearm are concentrated, arranged diagonally, abundant and thick folds that constitute the'balteus' of the mantle. On the left forearm both ends of the mantle, which come from the "baltus" and the left shoulder, are collected, to fall heavily from here in longitudinal and thick folds. [...] The dorsal part appears covered by the mantle forming oblique, wide and rounded folds just outlined, which reveal the curved forms of the hip and right buttocks.
He continues his description indicating that 'represents a contained movement, a' counter-movement 'adopted by the different parts: the left leg supports the weight of the body and the hip remains rigid, describing a curve, while the right leg appears discharged by the slight warned twist in the knee
the left shoulder is higher than the right, forcing the sculptor to place the breasts in a similar position. The folds of both the knife and the mantle highlight said 'contratroposto'.
It has a careful composition and a detailed execution, having been made to be seen in a frontal position. As a result of the transparency and texture of the fabric, the shape of the breasts, the belly, the hips, and both legs are perfectly observed. In the mantle, especially in the'balteus' and the part hanging from the left shoulder, the trephine work and the effects of chiaroscuro are concentrated.
He lacks his head, which was embedded in the gap that remains between the shoulders. He has lost his right arm at the level of the forearm, with an irregular fracture that starts from the shoulder, and the left hand. It is very damaged in the entire left arm. In the dorsal part the shoulder area is fractured. The lower part of the sculpture is lost with a fracture under the right knee and mid-calf left, which rises from it affecting the cloth hanging from the arm. In general, the preserved is in good condition, except for some breaks in the edges of several folds.

Description:
.A. Garriguet (Córdoba in the time of Seneca, 1996, p.50) describes this piece as a female head of natural size and slightly inclined towards the left side, corresponding to a woman of mature age whose hairstyle, of classicist cut, is structured on the front and temples in two lateral bands of wavy hair divided by a central stripe. These bands cover the ears partially and end up being gathered next to the nape of the neck in a wide bow formed by four braids.
The face, oval and fleshy, narrows considerably in the chin area. The countenance transmits serenity and we can even say a certain sweetness. The eyebrows are broad. The eyes, large, are very open. The mouth, on the other hand, is small and has thin lips. The conical shape of the neck indicates that this head was inserted in its day in an independent figure, today lost.
The entire surface is quite eroded, presenting a porous appearance caused by the action of organic agents, although this does not prevent to appreciate the characteristics of the hairstyle and the features of the face. The nose is fragmented at the approximate height of the tip.

Museum: Museo Etnológico y arqueológico de Córdoba
Description:
Following the description by JAº Garriguet (2001, p.30), we find ourselves before a female statue that wears'chiton' and'himation' (we use the Greek name for clothing since this sculpture takes both the model and the dress of a tardy type) very tight. The first of these two garments is only visible just below the neck, where it constitutes small folds in the shape of 'V', and in the lower part of the legs, as well as on both feet. Here the folding is thorough, fine and, in some cases, quite deep. Above the tunic is the mantle that wraps the entire figure, including the arms and head, highlighting the volumes and the resounding forms of the female anatomy. Due to the marked twisting of the body towards the left side, the folds of the dress follow very different directions, which contributes to grant a greater sensation of sinuous movement to the already moved sculpture by its marked contraposto. Of narrow shoulders, the statue has the right arm fallen and glued to the flank of the same side, whereas the left one bends to gather with the hand the thick folds of the mantle that, coming from the head, cross diagonally from the right clavicle until the left side. From here the mantle fell in straight folds towards the ground. Contrary to what usually happens, it is the right leg that appears totally upright and acting as the main element of sotén. The left is, however, flexed and delayed with respect to the previous one. Of the closed shoes, 'calcei muliembres', only the tip is appreciated.
The delicacy and care are present in its execution, so the sculptor knows and expresses perfectly and with great beauty the technique of wet cloths, which allows us to observe the female anatomy.
The work of the trepan is applied in very specific areas such as the upper edge of the mantle and the lower part of the 'chiton', which gives rise to profuse contrasts of chiaroscuro, so that the artist makes modeling prevail over the trepan
at all times the soft and light forms of the female anatomy predominate against the concentrations of cloths that hide the sensuality of the body of these ladies.
It stands on a plinth, worked with pointer, which presents its lost fronts.
Indicates I. López López (1998, p.68), that the sculpture is fractured in different parts, presenting a main break below the knees that divides the piece into two large fragments. The back is completely destroyed, in some areas pointer remains to fit other pieces. The neck is preserved
the right shoulder and left side have been lost from the waist to the knee, the folds hanging from the shoulder and forearm and part of the left leg, as a consequence of the aforementioned main fracture. The folds of the 'himation' have numerous breaks in its edges. We must note that the piece keeps both hands.

Description:
Incomplete male sculpture conserved in 4 fragments corresponding to the area of ​​the legs and belly, abdomen, chest and part of the head. The most deteriorated part is the right, where it lacks the shoulder and arm, in addition it does not conserve the left forearm, as well as part of the cornucopia. Part of the leg is also missing in the area of ​​the calves and both feet.
It is about a young man lying on a bed. Presents the head raised, turned to the left, facing the viewer. The part of the head conserves rest of the hair based on small and curled strands. The face, although it is lost almost in its entirety-it conserves only part of the nose, mouth and cheeks-reflects the features of a teenager with soft features and serene expression. The left arm is flexed, resting on it a cornucopia and covered in part by the mantle. The cornucopia presents several fruits in which the trepan has been used: wheat spike, bunch of grapes, vine leaf and, perhaps, figs. The body rests on the left arm, keeping the shoulders and head erect. The figure wrapped its lower part with a mantle, which climbs up the back, covering the bed, and is collected in the left arm. (Loza Azuaga, 1993)

Description:
It is deteriorated in the beard, nose, forehead and headdress. The front part of the bust and the left side of the headdress are reconstructed in another material. Only the front is worked, with the sides, bottom and back completely smooth, due to the frontal point of view for which it was designed.
It is a representation of Hercules, in which we are shown in mature age, bearded and with the touch of fig leaves as the most significant iconographic elements. The aspect that presents is of a robust man
the neck is wide, mouth closed with thick lower lip, cheeks marked and broad, round eyes with empty sockets, narrow forehead and small ears. The expression that shows the face is of certain pathos. (Peña Jurado, 2002, 33)
Reasoned classification: The sculptural work carried out presents a finish in which no detail is highlighted, it is only finished in broad strokes. Although the tufts of hair and beard are differentiated by incisions. Nor is there much use of the trepan, applying only to open grooves in the right pendant of the headdress or in the lower rows of the beard, as well as in the corners of the lips and vine leaves. All these resources are specific to the date in which this piece was framed (Neronian-Flavian period).

Description: Terracotta figurine representing a gladiator standing and standing. It consists of a hollow body largely and two molded legs hanging from the inside of the figure. It is armed with a square shield, held with the left arm and attached to the chest, covering this and the waist. With his right hand he wields a curved blade sword, also attached to the chest and next to the shield. The features of the face are limited to the prominence of the nose and the cavities of the eyes. The head is touched with a helmet, with a thick flange like a visor, and a conical spout pointing forward

Description:
Female bust of terracotta modeled by hand. The head, disproportionate in relation to the rest of the body represented, appears erect and facing forward: straight back nose, large almond-shaped eyes, with empty sockets for later filling, fine and marked eyebrows, mouth parted lips and gesture twisted, soft cheekbones and chin forward. The ears are large, well drawn, with the perforated lobe. A broad forehead is partially concealed by a hairstyle that divides the hair divided at the center into two thick braided strands. Three undulating strands fall on the shoulders. Above the head shows a headband in the shape of a crescent.
The neck is tall and narrow and at its base, at the sides, it has two perforations, possibly intended to hold a necklace or similar piece that falls on the neckline of the one represented. She is dressed in a pleated tunic with V-neckline. The arms, disproportionate and smaller in relation to the head, are folded and collected on the chest. The hands, open and extended with the palms facing up, are at the level of the sternum. In the left hand he holds a small figure of four-legged animal, with a long neck, elongated head with snout, almond-shaped eyes and pointed ears, which leans over the bowl in the form of a sphere segment that he holds with his right hand.
The piece was designed for a basically frontal point of view, so that the back barely molds the volumes and, in the case of the hair, the hairs are drawn through comb incisions. The holes that appear on the sides of the base of the neck come out from the back.
The interior of the bust is essentially hollow, showing walls of considerable thickness

Description:
The sculpture, made in bronze, appeared very fragmented and incomplete. It represents an emperor in military garb and divinized, as deduced from his bare feet. The proposals of reconstruction of the sculpture interpret it in attitude of ad locutio, asking for silence before the harangue to the troops, relating it with the Augusto of Prima Porta (García and Bellido 1963: 91) or in the position of dominatio, submitting to some fallen enemy (Corzo 1989: 325-326
Mora Piris 1997: 354). Gamer (1968) broadly admits the reconstruction of García and Bellido, although he doubts about the iconographic parity with Augusto de Prima Porta (see Trillmich 1990: 46). He would be standing, with his right arm raised and with his left, partially preserved, flexed and advanced, holding the mantle (of which part of the fall is preserved) on the forearm and holding with his hand half-closed some object (stick, cane or similar).

Description:
Female hand made of terracotta. The head, disproportionate in relation to the rest of the body represented, appears erect and facing forward: straight back nose, large almond-shaped eyes, with empty sockets for later filling, fine and marked eyebrows, lips parted, inexpressive
soft cheekbones and chin forward. The ears are large, well drawn, with the perforated lobe. A broad forehead is partially concealed by a hairstyle that divides the hair divided at the center into two thick braided strands. On these tufts, in front of the crown-shaped headband, two small semicircular appendages with a straight cut at the ends, representing small wings, can be seen. Three undulating strands fall on the shoulders.
The neck is narrow and at its base, on the sides, has two perforations, possibly intended to hold a necklace or similar piece that falls on the neckline of the represented. She is dressed in a pleated tunic with a V-neckline, showing the modeling of her right breast beneath her. The right arm, disproportionate and smaller as the other in relation to the head, appear raised vertically, showing the palm of the open hand in front. The left arm is folded up on the chest and holding a container that surrounds with fingers and a conical lid that ensures with the thumb. At the height of the dolls, there are two bracelets or, more likely, the top of the sleeves of the garment, in the form of a simple braid.
The piece was designed for a basically frontal point of view, so that the back barely molds the volumes and, in the case of the hair, the hairs are drawn through comb incisions. The holes that appear on the sides of the base of the neck come out from the back.
The interior of the bust is essentially hollow, showing walls of considerable thickness.

Description:
Head with the representation of a bearded senior man. Wide forehead furrowed by wrinkles, large eyes and robust nose - partially mutilated. The mouth is thin, covered by an abundant mustache
the ears are of great proportions. Does not keep the neck and has various chafing and imperfections all over the surface. Portrait of a private individual who reproduces the idealized archetype of the philosopher Chrysippus, who was quite accepted in the Roman world. Possibly it was placed in a domus, although it is possible that it could correspond to a funerary representation, following the fashion of portraits of sarcophagi in which the deceased was represented as a philosopher, especially during the third century (Amores, Beltrán and González, 2008 : 225-226). It was located in an emiral era deposit.

Description:
Figure of Mithras represented in the common oriental attire, in the Persian style: long pants fitted at the ankles, short tunic or chiton, chlamys tied to the neck and a Phrygian cap. The young man subdues the bull by holding him by the nose while he plunges the dagger into his neck and turns his head to look at the sun. From the purifying blood that flows from the bull drinks the dog, faithful friend of Mithras, who guards the soul. The serpent at the feet of Mithras produces the plants and the scorpion devours its testicles from which animals and people are born.
The work, made in a round shape, offers a basically frontal perspective.

Front of the head. Incision, Capital, Latin, Cultual.
DEA CAEL (estis) IVS (sit) [This piece alludes to the cult of the Dea Caelestis, although it may also be related to the cult of Isis Caelestis deity located in the environments of Itálica in Seville and Baelo Claudio in Cádiz.];
Find spot: Santuario de Torreparedones, Baena (Campiña Alta (comarca), Córdoba)
Description:
Head, ex-voto fragment carved in beige limestone.
The head presents carved the typical hair of the Iberian melena - helmet that frames the face. The facial features are characterized by their appreciable classicism in the lips, nose and something less in eyes (two ovals), which have hardly been worked on although their dimensions are outstanding.
The difference in treatments of existing surfaces is striking, since the face has been perfectly polished while the hair is rough and rough.
On the forehead of the head is an incised Latin graphite'Dea Caelestis' which possibly alludes to the deity to which it was dedicated.
Reasoned classification:
"The Iberian religion was a ritual proper to the indigenous population of the Iberian Peninsula, which differed from that practiced by the colonizing peoples.
In a first period the Iberian religion was based on the world of tombs, to move to a more public practice in the fourth century BC.
From this date a series of public sanctuaries are built, in which a series of zoomorphic votive offerings (bulls, lions, griffins, sphinxes, ...) have been found, as well as a series of anthropomorphic votive offerings of clear oriental influence ( for example the possible representation of the Goddess Demeter of Punic exportation). This type of votive offerings had the function of serving as an intermediary between the earthly and divine worlds. This type of pieces tell us the complexity of the ritual in which besides votive offerings we could find perfumes, libations,
These types of figurative representations can be found in clay, stone or bronze, adopting a wide variety of attitudes.
The votive offerings were made in workshops as the result of a demand from an elite clientele
that required a series of medium-sized sculptures, stereotyped and dressed in civilian clothes. The female votive offerings of this type were represented in full body, seated on a throne and with the hands arranged on the knees. These figures were dressed in the typical Iberian form, with a series of fine overlaid cloaks collected with fibulae and clasps, touched by a veil
They also used to be ornamented with a wide repertoire of jewels, such as tiaras, ring earrings, bracelets, necklaces with pendants (buckles or cases), ...,
The Sanctuary of Torreparedones is located south of the Iberian city found between Castro del Río and Baena (Córdoba) next to the city wall. We have found architectural remains from the Roman era, in addition to numerous pieces that reveal the function of this space as a sanctuary, among which we can highlight small sculptures mostly made of stone, ceramics and some reliefs. The appearance of Roman remains only demonstrates the continuity of religious activity in this center and the adoption of some elements, as in the case of votive offerings in which Latin inscriptions with Roman roots sometimes appear. The first remains of architecture are dated around the fourth century a.C. although there are vestiges that can be dated in the second century and that are taken as the initial date of the activity of this sanctuary.
This site has been dated sometimes taking into account the style with which they are performing localized votive offerings, which tell us that they belong to the IV - III century BC, although the outfits with which they appear instead date it in the second century - I to. C. For this reason it can be deduced that this workshop could have activity during the first Roman period taking into account the costumes, but that its artistic quality was very rough and rudimentary following the Iberian tradition itself.

Find spot: Torreparedones., Baena (Campiña Alta (comarca), Córdoba)
Description:
Following the description of Isabel López (1998, pp. 39-40), the sculpture is dressed in a tunic, whose'inus', with folds that start from the left shoulder and pass over the hip and part of the right leg, draws an extensive deep folds mass. It has a wide "ballet" that fits the waist, structured in three large irregular folds that give this part of the toga great movement. On the'balteus' supports the'umbo', with an elongated shape, in'U'. Under the'ima toga', which reveals the shapes of the hip and the left leg, conceiving the almost smooth tissue, with only a few thin and spaced folds, appears what is preserved of the 'lacinia', constituted by four small longitudinal folds . The sculptor perfectly masters the technique of the trepan in the realization of the folds, giving the garment great mobility and plasticity, as well as contrasts in luminosity.
The weight of the figure falls on the left leg, showing completely vertical and with some rigidity, while the right side gives a clear impression of relaxation and rest, perceptible in the leg, exonerated and carried forward. The right arm, which fitted into the sculpture at the level of the elbow by means of a retained iron bolt, is represented as fallen, although slightly advanced, while the left one is bent at the level of the elbow, with the hand facing forward, bearing some object. The left hand and the head were separate pieces that were set in the holes that have been preserved in the arm and neck. Attached to the left side of the toga is the 'capsa', configured in a very simple way, like a cylinder decorated with bands made by incisions. The back of the sculpture is worked very briefly, covered by just insinuated folds that lack the volume and plasticity of the anterior part.
The condition is excellent, despite the loss of the lower part from the ankles approximately. It is fractured in the neck and in the right shoulder, it is missing the right arm and part of the left one and some of the folds of the sinus are fractured.
Reasoned classification:
I. López (1998, pp. 39-40), points out that the model taken for the realization of this sculpture is the Augusto Vía Labicana, basing itself for such affirmation on parallelizable details between both sculptures as the fall in the fold of several folds of the ' sinus' on the shoulder, the edge of the'inus' or the lower area of ​​the toga arranged in four consecutive planes. Due to its typological characteristics, it is adapted to the togates that Goette classifies as type Ba, specifically in the group of the claudia era, this researcher classifying the piece from Cordoba in said group of togas claudios. It is also related to another togado of the Roman National Museum, coming from Rome and dated in the claudia period, which allows to date the piece at the beginning of the aforementioned period.
In this publication, the origin of the togado is Espejo, but according to data provided by the Director of the Baena Museum, Mr. José Antonio Morena López, this piece was found in the Torreparedones deposit

Description:
Seated Iberian ex-voto carved in beige limestone.
The piece appears sitting on an almost nonexistent throne, in which the extremities (hands and feet) are highlighted with small incised parallel lines that simulate the fingers of these limbs. The hands are collected on the belly, an attitude typical of the Iberian females that can symbolize gratitude to the continuity of their line through reproduction. Description:
Fragment of Iberian votive offering that represents the body of a human figure carved in beige limestone.
The sculpture is composed of a resounding block of limestone on which the volume of a body of a human figure dressed in a long tunic has been carved. The body configures the main volume of the piece, which at the back presents part of the limestone on which it has been carved, which acts as a backdrop, of rectangular shape and as a counterweight
also in the lower area there is a pedestal on which the ex-voto rises.
The lower and upper limbs have been drawn on the limestone by a series of bas-reliefs, complemented by small intions that mark the fingers as well as the ends of the tunic. The upper extremities are placed on the belly in a prayerful attitude, which has been interpreted as gratitude to the continuity of their lineage through reproduction. A continuity that in this ex voto has been represented not only by the attitude of the hands, but also with the state of pregnancy presented by the figure as indicated by the large volume of his belly.
The polishing treatment of the piece has been very careful especially for the front face, which is going to be the one that is going to be exposed
On the other hand, the piece has not been worked so much, in fact you can see the traces that have been produced in the carving.
The ex-voto has suffered the loss of the head, hence the sex we have deducted in this case by the state of pregnancy of the figure.

Description: Semi-naked male figure, headless, reclining on his left side, resting on a vessel through which water would flow. Description: Portrait of the Empress Sabina, made of white marble. Serene and distant face, with flat and elongated cheeks, stern gesture and hairstyle made with braids. Its state of conservation is very poor, since it is very eroded and has various chafing and fractures in various areas of the face
Hair: bun and hair band
Reasoned classification:
This head of the Empress Sabina entered the Museum through the Commission of Monuments, coming from the Italian collections gathered in the Section of Antiquities of the Museum of Paintings in 1854. Such circumstances allow us to suppose that it was recovered in the excavations of Francisco de Bruna in the eighteenth century, or perhaps in the Ivo de la Cortina between 1839 and 1840. Despite its poor state of preservation, the features that define the young empress are clearly distinguished, above all their expression and the braid hairstyle style of his mother Matidia. These details allow to include it in the type known as "Vaison", corresponding to a group of portraits that present her as "Augusta", a title she received in the year 128, at the same time that her husband Adriano assumed the title of "Pater Patriae".
The presence of Sabina in the Aelia Augusta Colony would have to be related to the importance of its political role in the Roman State, within the program of public propaganda around the imperial family, and even with the adhesion of the Italian elites to the cult dynastic of the Antonine emperors. From the Traianeum comes the inscription of a freedman of his, Autarques, asking for his health and for that of the emperor, in fulfillment of a vote to Silvano Panteo. Likewise, numerous coins with their effigy have been located in various parts of the city. Although Sabina has gone down in history only as "uxor Hadriani" (Adriano's consort), her influence was decisive in the development of imperial policy and in the maintenance of a dynastic legitimacy that her husband did not possess by lineage. Their marriage, prepared by the divinizada Plotina - wife of Trajano-, allowed the ascent of another family clan of the Bética, the Aelios, to the cusp of the Empire

Description: Male head with idealized features, turned in a slight foreshortening to the left. It maintains an expression of yearning and sublimation, and has an exuberant mane of curly strands, tied by a ribbon that knots behind. The lower end of the neck indicates that it was part of a larger statue
Hair: curly
Reasoned classification:
This magnificent head of Alexander was recovered in 1839 by the archaeologist Ivo de la Cortina in the Foro de Itálica. The piece became part of the Section of Antiquities of the Museum of Paintings of the city and in 1880 it entered the Museum through the Commission of Monuments. R. Thouvenot made her known as the head of Apollo or perhaps of Dionysus, but it was Antonio Garcia and Bellido who identified her with Alexandros, the Macedonian hero. It is the most unique image of the character, for its extraordinary beauty and originality. It represents the young and beautiful hero, with the hair raised on the forehead (anastolé) and the tape that holds it (taenia), as an attribute of royalty. Its technique and formal composition refer to the style of the second century, in line with other known portraits of the character, although with slight variations in the composition of the face and hair, which make the piece of Italy an exceptional model. The gentle turn of the head, its delicate features and the exuberant aureole of curls approach it to other museums, but the anatomical details and its dreamy expression determine its particular iconography, clearly reminiscent of Helios and Antinous (León, 1995).
Its function is inserted in the sculptural program developed in the Adriaan period in the city, following an ideological constant tending to link the Colony with the Genius of Rome, and with the heroic and conquering feeling of its native emperors, Trajan and Adriano (Camacho, 2014 )

Reasoned classification: Figurine of Egyptian elaboration, with the representation of Ptah, Amón or Anubis, integrated into the cult area of the Italian amphitheater from the reuse of an original from the Nile Delta (Gamer-Wallert, 1998). Description: Portrait of elderly woman, with wavy hair and wearing a veil. Realistic features, with prominent cheekbones, marked jaw, deep eyes and small mouth. The nose, partially mutilated, is wide. In the lobe of his right ear there is a hole that indicates that he was able to carry added earrings. Its proportion and fracture of the neck indicate that it must have been part of a complete statue, somewhat smaller than the natural one. The upper part is fractured, at the height of the forehead, and has numerous concretions and breaks throughout the surface. Coarse-grained marble, with exterior patina
Reasoned classification: This head was located in the Iseion of Itálica, next to six votive marble plates embedded in the floor of access to the temple, with the representation of footprints of foot (vestige), of which three conserved inscriptions dedicated to Isis and one to Bubastis. It has been identified as an isiacal priestess, due to the context of its finding and its features of old age, although some authors have questioned this identification because there are no iconographic features that make it possible to specify it. A recent analysis returns to her identification as an Isis priestess and relates it to a portrait located in the sanctuary of Diana Nemorensis in Nemi, in the Aricia ager, near Rome, by the type of headdress that both heads share, the Miter Lydia. The iconography of this element is related to activities of the daily cult, in which adortrices, estolistas and hieróstolas participate (those who looked after and dressed the images of the goddesses), although the cases of Itálica and Nemi seem to point to portraits of high priestesses range (Beltrán, 2015)

Description:
This head, bigger than the natural and correct invoice, represents a young character with characteristic hairstyle Julyclaudia. It has practically lost all the forehead and the top of the skull, which was worked in a different piece, attached to the rest of the head by a metal bolt. He also has a fractured nose and presents breaks and chipping of varying consideration in eyes, cheeks, lips and chin.
The head tilts towards the right side and rotates slightly in the same direction, as the neck musculature suggests. According to Pilar León (2001, p.286), some physiognomic features, such as the shape of the face, the large eyes, the thin lips in the shape of a Cupid's bow
some characteristics of the hairstyle of tufts moved, swirling forward on the side and deep down on the neck, where they adopt a horizontal arrangement, stylized in S and with the tips turned down
the combination of factors such as the iconographic scheme, to the extent that it is possible to recognize it, and the larger than natural dimensions, alluding to an official character, deserve to be highlighted because they are representative, resulting in portraits of unsafe designation but undoubtedly ascribed to members of the Julio-Claudia family.
Hair: characteristic Iulio-claudian hairstyle

Description: Figure exempt of lion, carved in limestone of whitish tonality. It does not keep the front legs or the back right. The left rear claw and part of the face are also missing. Originally it was crouched, with the front legs resting on the ground and the hindquarters raised. The head is of medium size, oriented to the left, with the jaws half open, revealing part of the denture. Large, well-marked eyes and abundant mane around the face and neck, based on thick elongated strands, curved and imbricated with each other. The ribs are marked through a series of parallel incisions, as well as the musculature of the upper part of the front legs. The tail is rolled up on the left rear leg, with the end indicated by incisions. It keeps a quadrangular plinth decorated with swastikas. Originally it was coated and polychrome
Reasoned classification: The lion of El Coronil is one of the most singular specimens of this Museum, for its design and for the decoration of the supporting plinth. It presents a series of esváticas in relief, of the type of those found in some funerary monuments of Salaria and Cástulo in the High Guadalquivir, dated in high imperial period. Possibly it was part of a mausoleum located in the Roman site known as Venta de la Mina (Ruiz Delgado, 1985: 88), or perhaps in one of the important enclaves documented in the surroundings of the town, such as the Roman city of Salpensa. Its composition and design is very similar to another specimen preserved in this Museum (CE25992), from Utrera, being possible, as in this case, that the copy of El Coronil held an animal head under the paw. Surely he was on the right side of the grave

Description: It represents a woman standing with her left leg slightly flexed. She is dressed in the fashion of the classical Greek era, that is, a long, thin tunic or chiton cinched to the body, tied under the breasts with a knotted ribbon. The tunic falls to the feet and only shows part of the left. It is covered with mantle or himatión that takes on the back and left shoulder falling in cascade of folds on this side. The other end of the mantle covers the right side under the arm and crosses in front to gather on the left forearm with profusion of folds that are confused with those formed by the other end. The sculpture is very good invoice. It lacks the head, the right arm and the hands, which must have been independent pieces to adjust them after the sculpture. The gaps in these parts of the body that the statue presents thus seem to confirm it. It presents a vertical fissure in the left arm.

Description:
Sculpture that represents a character in military clothing. It has a breastplate, whose front has been decorated with winged Victories that flank a candelabra. At the lower end, it has two rows of rounded lamas and ornamented with motifs of masks and palm trees or other vegetal motifs. Around the neck it has the military mantle or paludamentum that knots on the right shoulder.
It shows deterioration in its surface, it has lost by breakage the head, the right arm from the shoulder, the left from the elbow and the legs from the thighs.

Reasoned classification: Piece of special relevance within the protohistórica plastic of the Iberian Peninsula, for its transcendence as a symbol of the Tartessian culture from its possible identification with King Argantonio. Wrapped in mystery since its discovery in the heart of the Huelva mines, it perpetuates to the present that message of historiography about a character that transmits nobility and serenity. Carriazo, without deviating from that historical evocation, conceives it as a hybrid production, in which elements of Greek, Oriental and Punic culture are fused, on a local, indigenous basis, during the period of apogee of the colonial Tartesian world

Description: Fragment of thoracatus from which only the lower half of the torso and the legs up to the knees have been preserved. The surface of the piece is so eroded that you can barely distinguish the motifs that adorned the shell made of vegetal scrolls. Santos Jener (1944, p.83) also points out the presence on the left side of the torso of a gripping paw. Two rows of lambrequins of different size and shape (narrower, shorter and pointed superiors) and decorated with motifs totally lost today, hang from the aforementioned cuirass. Under them a row of long launas is also very deteriorated, although in some the work of the trepan is still appreciated. The back treatment of the piece can be considered acceptable.
